course.description: This course surveys European history and culture since the Reformation. Topics include the impact of Protestantism, the development of nation-states, the Enlightenment, revolutionary ideas and experiences, the Napoleonic era, imperialism, mass political movements, and global warfare. Through original texts, historical studies, and literature, students explore relations among religions, states and societies and understandings of liberty and reason, natural environments, family life, and gender roles. Offered annually.
course.name: Europe: 1492-Present
course.title: Colonialism & Europe: 1492-Present

course.description: This course begins with the Communist revolution of 1917 and traces the growth of the Soviet Union under Lenin, Stalin, and their successors. Students analyze the "crisis" of the Soviet system in order to explain why the last of the European empires collapsed in 1991. Language Across the Curriculum (LAC) course periodically available in Russian. Offered alternate years.
course.name: People and Power in Soviet Russia

course.description: Students learn and apply yoga principles of physical fitness and emotional wellness through a blend of yoga postures, movements, relaxation, breathing techniques, and mindfulness.
course.name: Classical Hatha Yoga
course.notes: Yoga mat required.

course.description: How do the peoples of Latin America participate politically? How do domestic politics interact with national and international economics? How do states treat challenges posed by migration and by desires for "modernization" and democracy in a context of authoritarian legacy and debt? Students examine how Latin American politics work, focusing on Mexico, parts of Central America, the Caribbean, the Andean Region, and the Southern Cone. Also counts toward Latin American studies major and Latin American studies and business and management studies concentrations.
course.name: Latin American Politics

course.description: The course introduces core questions, concepts, and theories of international relations. Topics vary, ranging from persistent problems and enduring themes in global relations to Prominent questions confronting scholars of international relations. The course highlights methods and practices of political science research and includes a major research project. Also counts toward international relations concentration. Prerequisites: PSCI 220 and one course in the subfield, or permission of instructor.
course.name: Sem: International Relations
course.notes: Open only to seniors.
course.prerequisites: Prerequisites: PSCI 220 and one course in the subfield, or permission of instructor.
course.title: Seminar in International Relations

course.description: This course provides a comprehensive research opportunity, including an introduction to relevant background material, technical instruction, identification of a meaningful project, data collection and analysis, and writing. The topic is determined by the faculty member in charge of the course and may relate to their research interests. This course meets the Writing in the Major requirements for Biology majors. Offered based on department decision. May be offered as a 1.00 credit course or .50 credit course. Prerequisite: determined by instructor.
course.name: Research:
course.notes: Registration by invitation of the professor.
course.title: Directed Undergraduate Research with Writing

course.description: Students learn conducting techniques for choral literature including research-based rehearsal techniques, vocal preparation, score study, and video self-evaluation of gesture and rehearsal. Course work also includes observation of conductors on campus and in the community. Offered annually in the fall semester. Prerequisite: MUSIC 251.
course.name: Choral Conducting

course.description: This course examines the ethics of ambition and leadership through diverse normative perspectives. By exploring historical examples and theoretical approaches from Plato to the present, students reflect on ambition as both a fundamental human drive and a key force in civic leadership. They also assess its moral and practical risks for individuals and communities. Finally, students consider how their own ambitions relate to their personal and public roles within a political community. Offered alternate years during spring semester.
course.name: Ambition, Leadership, and Politics

course.description: Drawing from the fields of biology, neuroscience, psychology, and sociology, this course offers a deep dive into the psychology of music performance anxiety. Students develop an understanding of (1) the sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems, (2) causes, triggers, and symptoms of music performance anxiety, and (3) the current state of music performance anxiety research including prevention, intervention, and treatment protocols. Students complete a literature survey examining both quantitative and qualitative research on a topic related to music performance anxiety. Prerequisite: MUSIC 141 or permission of instructor.
course.name: Music Performance Anxiety

course.description: In an age of information overload, stories can rise above the noise. Effective organizational storytelling helps to engage an intended community on a meaningful and emotional level. Students will explore the craft of storytelling and study a variety of media (analogue and digital) on which the story can be delivered. The course will include case study analysis, group work and client-based projects. Offered annually. Prerequisite: sophomore standing or above.
course.name: Organizational Storytelling

course.description: Introductory study of selected topics in physics in a full-semester format. Topics are chosen to engage students in physics based on available staff. Offered periodically during spring semester. Potential topics include quantum computing, astrophysics and the physics of energy.
course.name: Introductory Topics in Physics
course.notes: Students that have taken or are currently taking PHYS 244 are not eligible to
take this course.
Open only to first-year students and a limited number of sophomores.

revisions.notes: Students that have taken or are currently taking PHYS 244 are not eligible to
take this course.
Open only to first-year and sophomore students.

course.description: Students continue learning Spanish in an intercultural context. The course continues to examine the Spanish-speaking world through exploration of topics, for example: cities and urban life; housing; and the historical roots of culinary traditions and food production. In-class speaking, listening, reading, and writing activities are complemented by attendance at two required culture tables. Offered each semester and January Term. Does not count toward Spanish major. Prerequisite: SPAN 111 or placement into SPAN 112.
course.name: Intro Spanish Language/World II
course.title: Introduction to Spanish Language and the Spanish-Speaking World II

course.description: Students study topics in biology. Topics vary from year to year at the discretion of the department. Class work depends on the topics and instructor, but is consistent with the amount and level of work in other 200-level biology courses. May be repeated if topics are different. Counts as an elective toward biology major. May count toward other majors or concentrations if approved by the chair of that major/concentration. Offered periodically each term. Prerequisites: vary.
course.name: Top: Mycology
course.notes: Prerequisite: BIO 150
course.title: Topics in Biology

course.description: Writing and Rhetoric courses, taught by faculty across the college, engage students in writing for multiple purposes and audiences. Each course explores a contemporary question of interest to college students. Students write in multiple genres and engage in writing as a systematic process with opportunities to respond to feedback. They learn, evaluate, and use appropriate technologies to explore, discuss, and write about course content. This course is limited to first-year students and sophomores.
course.name: Top: Indigenous Voices
course.notes: Section topic: Indigenous Voices
course.title: Writing and Rhetoric

course.description: This course offers an in-depth investigation of a selected topic from Norwegian literary or cultural history. Topics may be organized by period (Realism, Postwar literature), historical events (literature and World War II), important themes (feminism, social democracy, religion and secularism), or genre (Norwegian poetry, literature and film). The course also emphasizes development of critical, interpretive, and research skills, as well as refinement of Norwegian language proficiency. This course is taught in Norwegian. Offered annually. Prerequisite: NORW 253 or equivalent.
course.name: Top: Amerikafeber
course.notes: Course topic: Amerikafeber: Fra Pionerer til Glemte Skjebner
course.title: Topics in Norwegian Literature/Culture

course.description: From classical form to avant garde, this course introduces students to the various artistic representations of Asian calligraphy. Students explore the aesthetic concepts, evolution of different styles, and practical techniques of brush-written writings. Class lectures complement hands-on practice in which students master the basic strokes, structures, compositions, and movements that are involved in producing calligraphic work. Asian language knowledge is not required. All readings and demonstrations will be in English. Materials fee. Offered periodically.
course.name: Asian Calligraphy
course.title: The Art of Calligraphy: Techniques and Appreciation

course.description: Students study topics in biology. Topics vary from year to year at the discretion of the department. Class work depends on the topics and instructor, but is consistent with the amount and level of work in other 200-level biology courses. May be repeated if topics are different. Counts as an elective toward biology major. May count toward other majors or concentrations if approved by the chair of that major/concentration. Offered periodically each term. Prerequisites: vary.
course.name: Top: Sex Differences Human Health
course.notes: Prerequistie: BIO 150
course.title: Topics in Biology

course.description: Specific topics announced prior to each term are based on student interests and available staff. Class work includes comprehensive review of literature on the specific topic. Class meetings present topics in discussion format. May be repeated if topic is different. Also counts toward environmental studies major (all emphases) and concentration when taught with environmental science focus and approved by chair. Prerequisites: vary.
course.name: Top: Ecological Modeling
course.notes: Open to juniors and seniors only.
course.title: Selected Topics

course.description: This introductory course provides students a broad overview of public health focusing on concepts relating to health promotion, disease prevention and epidemiology. Additionally, students learn about the core public health values, functions, population health assessment and intervention and the socio-economic, behavioral, biological and environmental determinants of health. Students engage in oral and written communication to critically think and analyze public health issues. Offered during fall and January terms.
course.name: Introduction to Public Health

course.description: The American presidency is one of the most powerful political offices in the world. The actions and policies of U.S. presidents influence domestic governance, global affairs, and democratic institutions. This course examines the presidency's powers, constraints, and responsibilities, exploring the political processes that shape it. We analyze contemporary developments and historical trends, addressing key questions about nominations, institutional evolution, personal leadership, and the impact of social and economic forces, with a focus on the 21st-century presidency. Offered annually during spring semester.
course.name: American Presidency
course.title: The American Presidency

course.description: Students explore a topic pertinent to more than one geographic area of the Spanish-speaking world (Spain, Latin America, and/or the Hispanic U.S.). Students focus on comparative analysis through reading, discussion and writing in Spanish. The course includes study of at least one substantive literary work. Sample topics include: Dictatorship and Literature, and Language and Identity. May be repeated if topic is different. Taught in Spanish. Offered periodically. Prerequisite: SPAN 250 or SPAN 251 and at least one 270-level course.
course.name: Top: Narratives of Migration
course.notes: Prerequisite: Completion of SPAN 275.
course.prerequisites: SPAN 250 or SPAN 251 and at least one 270-level course.
course.title: Comparative "Hispanidades"

course.description: The department periodically offers courses on special topics. The specific title will be listed in the class and lab schedule when it is offered. Depending on course content, can also count toward Chinese and/or Japanese majors. Prerequisite: determined by instructor.
course.name: Top: Body in E Asian Women's Lit
course.title: Topics in Asian Studies

course.description: This survey of cognition examines how we acquire (perception, attention, learning), store (memory), communicate (language) and use knowledge (thinking, judgment, problem solving, decision making, creativity). Such issues influence how we educate people, evaluate eyewitnesses in court, convince consumers to buy products, and improve our memory or attention. Students will engage in hands-on activities as a part of the class to enhance our study of the mind. Offered annually. Prerequisite: PSYCH 125.
course.name: Cognitive Psychology

course.description: Why are certain experiences or patterns of behavior considered psychologically "abnormal?" Students investigate a wide array of psychological disorders, including anxiety disorders, depression, eating disorders, and schizophrenia. Students examine models used to conceptualize abnormal behavior, as well as current evidence and theories regarding the etiology and treatment of these important and sometimes devastating disorders. Offered each semester. Prerequisite: PSYCH 125.
course.name: Psychopathology

course.description: This course is an advanced study of eating disorders, as well as disordered eating and obesity. We will examine clinical diagnosis of eating disorders, causes and correlates in the development of eating disorders, prevention, and treatment. We will also examine how eating disorders affect individuals, families, romantic partners, friends, and those working with individuals who have eating disorders. Prerequisites: PSYCH 230 and PSYCH 247.
course.name: Sem: Eating Disorders
course.title: Issues in Psychology

course.description: Specific topics announced prior to each term are based on student interests and available staff. Class work includes comprehensive review of literature on the specific topic. Class meetings present topics in discussion format. May be repeated if topic is different. Also counts toward environmental studies major (all emphases) and concentration when taught with environmental science focus and approved by chair. Prerequisites: vary.
course.name: Top: Cellular Stress Response
course.notes: Open to Juniors and Seniors only.
course.title: Selected Topics

course.description: This interdisciplinary course introduces the field of Asian American Studies and the multiple cultural and historical productions of Asia and America, from art and film to food and lifestyles. Critical analysis of topics such as ethnic/cultural identities, stereotypes, citizenships, media/pop cultures, body images, sexuality, practices of different Asian communities, and various contemporary issues are explored through interactive in-class activities, films, presentations, and field trips. Offered periodically.
course.name: Asia in America

course.description: The last decade has unveiled the mechanism by which a single cell gives rise to an embryo rich in pattern and cellular diversity. This course traces the use of surgical, genetic, and molecular techniques as they have uncovered the developmental blueprints encoding the universal body plan fundamental to all metazoan life. Students attend lectures plus one three-hour laboratory per week. Offered periodically during Spring semester. Prerequisite: BIO 233 or BIO 227.
course.name: Developmental Biology
course.notes: Students registering for BIO 278 must also register for BIO 278 Lab A or Lab B.
This course fulfills the comparative organismal requirement of the BIO major.
This course no longer counts as a Biomolecular Science elective.

revisions.notes: Students registering for BIO 278 must also register for BIO 278 Lab A or Lab B.
This course was previously BIO 372. Students that have taken BIO 372 cannot take
this course. This course no longer counts as a Biomolecular Science elective.

course.description: This course provides the framework for understanding medical language and terminology used by healthcare professionals, and helps students learn common medical terms essential for safe patient care and effective communication between interprofessional healthcare teams. This course is intended for students preparing for graduate studies in nursing, physician assistant, occupational therapy, physical therapy and other allied health areas, and is not recommended for nursing majors or for students preparing to apply for admission into a school of medicine, dentistry or podiatry. Offered annually in the spring semester. Does not count toward biology major. Prerequisites: BIO 143 and BIO 243.
course.name: Medical Terminology (.25)
course.title: Medical Terminology

course.description: Since its invention, photography has shaped our ways of seeing, our social history, and our identities. Photography is also a compelling form of artistic expression. This course is an introduction to the history of photography from its origins to the present, including the role of photography in society and in the fine arts. Students learn the skills of formal visual analysis and critical thinking about the power of the photographic image in our lives. Offered periodically.
course.name: History of Photography
course.title: A History of Photography

course.description: This course surveys standard topics in the study of algorithms, with an emphasis on complexity analysis and implementation experience. Topics include asymptotic analysis, searching and sorting, divide and conquer, basic graph algorithms, greedy algorithms, dynamic programming, and NP-complete problems. Offered each semester. Prerequisites: MATH 234 and CSCI 251, or consent of the instructor.
course.name: Analysis of Algorithms
course.notes: Prerequisite: CSCI 251 and Math 234.
course.prerequisites: Prerequisites: MATH 234 and CSCI 251, or consent of the instructor.

course.description: This course explores the sources, chemical composition, and metabolic behavior of nutrients. Nutritional requirements for a balanced diet are examined as well as the consequences of excesses and deficiencies. Students use nutrition tools and guidelines to make sound food choices, learn how to read food labels, and consider factors affecting food consumption. Class activities increase students' awareness of a healthy diet, help students evaluate nutrition behaviors, and facilitate a nutritionally sound lifestyle. Offered annually. Does not count toward major, but is a prerequisite for the nursing major.
course.name: Nutrition and Wellness

course.description: This course is an introduction to modern and postmodern art and thought after World War II through a survey of painting, sculpture, and new-media arts. Students learn about celebrated art and artists, major values such as issues of identity informing their work, and ways of analyzing and making sense of newer art. Offered annually. Prerequisite: none, but at least one college art history or studio art course is recommended.
course.name: Art Since 1945
course.prerequisites: none, but at least one college art history or studio art course is recommended.

course.description: This course offers an expansion of ballet vocabulary and technique with an emphasis on movement quality, clarity, and efficiency. Outside work includes practicing, reading, writing, and concert attendance. Open to majors and other students with instructor's permission. Offered each semester. Prerequisite: two terms of DANCE 121 or DANCE 130 or DANCE 131 or permission of the instructor.
course.name: Ballet II
course.prerequisites: two terms of DANCE 121 or DANCE 130 or DANCE 131 or permission of the instructor.

course.description: This course offers an expansion of ballet vocabulary and technique with an emphasis on movement quality, clarity, and efficiency. Outside work includes practicing, reading, writing, and concert attendance. Open to majors and other students with instructor's permission. May be repeated. Offered each semester. Prerequisite: two terms of DANCE 121 or DANCE 130 or DANCE 131 or permission of the instructor.
course.name: Ballet II
course.prerequisites: two terms of DANCE 121 or DANCE 130 or DANCE 131 or permission of the instructor.

course.description: This praxis-based course is designed to empower students to develop a living definition of embodying activism when engaging with issues of race, power, privilege, and colonialism. Through multiple social justice perspectives, student activists define their own understanding of activism and discern how to participate in various forms of activism within a hybrid course that combines seminars, lectures, and studio practices. Student activists, centered on their living definition of Embodying Activism, interact with other activists, artivists, philosophies, and diverse techniques that prioritize embodiment as their primary method of inquiry within the United States. Having a performative background is strongly encouraged but is not a prerequisite.
course.name: Top: Embodying Activism
course.notes: This course includes an academic civic engagement (ACE) component.
course.title: Topics in Dance

course.description: This course examines Latin America's colonial history from 1492 to 1898. We will examine the history of Spanish, Portuguese and French imperialism in the region through the eyes of the people who lived it: Indigenous commoners and nobles, enslaved and freed people, women and children, scientists and entrepreneurs. With a specific focus on the history of human interaction with the region's diverse ecologies and the development of capitalism, on colonial law and the history of race and gender, we will ask how colonial society took shape, how these empires sustained themselves and why they eventually collapsed. Students will gain an appreciation for Latin America's central role in the modern history of global interconnection and understand how the specific dynamics of imperialism established the foundation for Latin America's postcolonial history.
course.name: Peoples of Colonial Latin America

course.description: This course explores topics in the history of Africa, Asia, or Latin America, designed to emphasize active skills of critical reading, textual and contextual analysis, historiographical argument, and historical writing. Recent topics have included "American Empire: A Cultural History of US-Latin America Relations" and "Imperialism and Nationalism in Southeast Asia." Primarily for history majors; others by permission of instructor. Offered periodically.
course.name: Sem: Cities in Latin American Hist
course.title: Methods Seminar: Histories of Africa, Asia, and Latin America

course.description: Students apply interdisciplinary theories and methods to selected topics in race and ethnic studies. The course employs a discussion format, focusing on critical reading and literary texts. Offered in alternate years. May be repeated if topic is different.
course.name: Sem: Critical Indigenous Studies
course.title: Topical Seminar

course.description: This course takes students on an exciting journey back to the world of the ancient Greeks, a land of democracy and tyranny, comedy and tragedy, myth and mystery - and much more. Students explore ancient Greek society from an interdisciplinary perspective, analyzing its literature, art, and ideas in the light of their historical and cultural contexts. The course ranges far, both chronologically and geographically, from the palaces of the Bronze Age to the Library of Alexandria. Offered every other year.
course.name: The World of the Ancient Greeks

course.description: In this course students explore and analyze a diversity of contemporary fiction and experiment with modes of a fiction writer's craft. Students workshop and critique each other's stories to better understand craft elements, the process of revision, and the dynamics of a literary community. Prerequisites: WRIT 120 or equivalent and at least sophomore status.
course.name: Fiction Writing
course.prerequisites: Prerequisites: WRIT 120 or equivalent and at least sophomore status.

course.description: This course introduces students to the study of physiological and functional adaptations to human movement. The field is richly interdisciplinary, involving such disciplines as anatomy, chemistry, biology, physics, physiology, biomechanics, motor control, psychology, nutrition, neuroscience, rehabilitative therapy, and exercise prescription. Rigorous and systematic study of these sub-fields enables students to understand how and why people move and the factors which limit and enhance the capacity to move. Offered annually.
course.name: Introduction to Kinesiology
course.notes: Open to all classes.

course.description: The course is rooted in advanced nutrition science and behavior-change psychology. Students examine the roles nutrient selection, metabolism, and timing play in supporting physical performance as well as mental and emotional health. Students discuss the integration and regulation of metabolism, energy expenditure, hydration, sleep, stress, and recovery; and they conduct an advanced overview of the functions of macronutrients, micronutrients, fluids, and supplements that are determinants of health and diseases. Offered annually. Prerequisite: BIO 143 and BIO 243; kinesiology major.
course.name: Performance Nutrition
course.notes: This course is open only to juniors and seniors.

course.description: The field of kinesiology is constantly expanding into new frontiers. This course provides an in-depth study of advanced topics that are chosen with attention to student interest and available staff. Class work depends on the topics and instructor, but is consistent with the amount and level of work in other 200-level kinesiology courses. May be repeated if courses are different. Counts as an elective toward the kinesiology major. May count toward other majors or concentrations if approved by the chair of that major/concentration. Offered periodically. Prerequisite: permission of the instructor.
course.name: Top: Motor Control/Learning Practic
course.notes: Full topic title: Motor Control and Learning Practices
This course is open only to seniors, junior and sophomores.
course.title: Topics in Kinesiology

course.description: This course explores the dance techniques of Party Dances, which began being termed "Hip Hop" dance in the 1980s. As a transformation of styles with Africanist parentage, this course focuses on the rhythm and groove embedded by the New York beginnings of proper Hip Hop. The course exposes students to the influence of Hip Hop on various cultures through the study of Party Dances and urban styles from New York to California, 1980s to now. May be repeated. P/N only. Offered each semester.
course.name: Hip Hop I

course.description: Storytelling is one of the oldest forms of theology. For Indigenous peoples, stories are sacred, they carry wisdom, covenant, and encounters with the Holy. This course explores Indigenous narratives from diverse tribal nations as sacred texts in their own right. Through creation accounts, visionary experiences, trickster tales, and contemporary Indigenous literature, we will examine how stories embody theology: teachings about the divine, humanity, land, kinship, healing, and future hope. Students will engage these narratives with the same seriousness given to scripture in other traditions, reflecting on story as sacred practice, theological revelation, and communal memory.
course.name: Top: Sacred Storytelling
course.notes: Full topic title: Sacred Storytelling: Indigenous Narratives and Theologies
course.title: Topics in Religion

course.description: Are religion and science in conflict? They have experienced significant tensions yet they owe much to each other. This course introduces students to science and religion in the modern era and how they map out distinct territories. Students examine the mutual influence of science and religion in forming conceptions about what nature, fact, and belief are, and how these notions have changed. Students investigate topics such as the denial of science, human origins, and emergence.
course.name: Religion and Science

course.description: Are religion and science in conflict? They have experienced significant tensions yet they owe much to each other. This course introduces students to science and religion in the modern era and how they map out distinct territories. Students examine the mutual influence of science and religion in forming conceptions about what nature, fact, and belief are, and how these notions have changed. Students investigate topics such as the denial of science, human origins, and emergence.
course.name: Religion and Science

course.description: Students expand their developing language skills by continuing to listen, speak, read, and write on topics familiar to them. They continue their study of social and cultural notions inherent in the daily life of peoples in diverse Francophone communities and learn to think critically and make interdisciplinary connections and informed cross-cultural comparisons. Offered during spring semester. Does not count toward French major. Prerequisite: FREN 111 or placement.
course.name: Beginning French II

course.description: Students explore a specified topic or theme in language, in literature, or in culture/civilization, or in a combination of these, through close reading, discussion, analysis, and interpretation of selected literary and/or non-literary works. Recent topics include "War and Terrorism," "Crime and Memory in Fiction," and "Translation Studies." May be repeated if topic is different. Taught in French. Offered annually. Prerequisite: minimum of one 270-level course.
course.name: Top: Lang/Ident/Poli Francoph Lit
course.notes: Full topic title: Language, Identity, and Politics in Francophone Literature
course.title: Topics in Francophone Studies

course.description: Students explore modern German history from the Enlightenment through the establishment of a modern German nation-state (1871), two World Wars and their aftermath, up to the late Cold War period when the question of how to frame Germany's modern history became a matter of public debate. By examining primary sources in English translation, critical historiography, and ethical perspectives, students learn not just the major turns in modern German history, but consider the ethical implications of revolutionary and revolutionizing movements and the ethics of history-writing itself. Students hone skills of interpretation and argumentation in writing and speaking. No prerequisites. Offered periodically.
course.name: Making Modern Germany
course.title: Ethics of Revolution: The Making of Modern Germany

course.description: This course introduces students to the ceramic processes of wheel throwing and hand building as means for creating works of art. Students learn terminology and critical approaches to ceramics. Students develop critical skills and the ability to analyze and interpret ceramic artwork. The course emphasizes creative approaches to solving visual problems through ceramic work. Slide presentations on contemporary and historical ceramics provide background for assignments and highlight the role of ceramics in various cultural contexts. Materials fee. Offered each semester.
course.name: Ceramics

course.description: This intermediate-level course assumes students have a substantial understanding of ceramic processes, plus a good awareness of their own interests in the realm of ceramic expression. The instructor helps students focus their efforts by proposing specific areas of investigation. Materials fee. Offered annually. Prerequisite: ARTS 207 or permission of instructor.
course.name: Intermediate Ceramics

course.description: Students explore a particular period or century through examination of selected literary and non-literary works within their socio-historical and cultural contexts. Coursework includes discussion, analysis, and interpretation of representative works. Sample topics: "19th-Century French Literature," "La Belle Epoque," and "20th-Century French Literature." May be repeated if period is different. Taught in French. Offered at least alternate years. Prerequisite: minimum of one 250-level course (two recommended).
course.name: Top: Memories of WW2
course.title: Period Studies

course.name: LAC - German
course.notes: Meeting time will be decided based on availability of the registered students.
Prerequisite: Completion of GERM 231 or equivalent experience. This course
cannot be wish listed. Add it after registering for HIST 224 (main course).
course.prerequisites: Completion of GERM 231 or equivalent experience. This course

course.description: This course offers selected surveys in historical studies. Topics depend on instructor. Recent topics have included "Women in Early America," "U.S.-Latin American Relations," and "Doing Public History." May be repeated if topic is different. Offered periodically.
course.name: Top: Capitalism & Ecology Latin Am
course.title: Topics in History

course.description: This course focuses on the film and/or media production of a particular nation, region, or economic and cultural partnership across borders. It gives students a historical overview of influential national and transnational cinemas, or other global media products. May be repeated if topics are different. Offered alternate years in the spring semester beginning spring semester 2021-22.
course.name: Top: The French New Wave
course.title: Topics: National and Transnational Film and Media

course.description: Why are the 1960s considered the "decade of the big change"? The era was one of global upheaval, political realignment, and cultural transformation. Through historical sources, film, literature, and media, students will explore how the decade reshaped ideas about power, identity, and protest across the U.S. and the wider world. The course emphasizes both a transnational historical context and collective memory, equipping students to analyze competing interpretations and consider the period's enduring influence. Offered periodically in spring semester.
course.name: The 1960s: History, Memory, Legacy

course.description: In the 17th and 18th centuries, the Age of Reason and Enlightenment sparked revolutions throughout Europe and the world. This course explores how the Nordic nations were shaped by this transformative era. Students analyze the impact of these global movements on Nordic history, examining new views on science, religion, and government. Students learn how these countries were an interconnected part of a revolutionary time, experiencing their own significant shifts in power, society, and culture. Offered periodically in spring semester.
course.name: Nordic Revolutions

course.description: What might it mean to live authentically? From social media to personal branding, authenticity is a common ethical concept, one oriented towards autonomy and self-realization. Yet, authenticity has a diversity of meanings, whether religious or non-religious. This course will explore authenticity by putting Luther, Kierkegaard, and Nietzsche into conversation with ideas of authenticity. Exploring themes such as divine action, freedom, sin, passion, and will to power, the class will interrogate the (im)possibility of becoming authentic. Offered periodically in spring semester.
course.name: Chasing Authenticity
course.title: Chasing Authenticity: Luther, Kierkegaard, and Nietzsche

course.description: What might it mean to live authentically? From social media to personal branding, authenticity is a common ethical concept, one oriented towards autonomy and self-realization. Yet, authenticity has a diversity of meanings, whether religious or non-religious. This course will explore authenticity by putting Luther, Kierkegaard, and Nietzsche into conversation with ideas of authenticity. Exploring themes such as divine action, freedom, sin, passion, and will to power, the class will interrogate the (im)possibility of becoming authentic. Offered periodically in spring semester.
course.name: Chasing Authenticity
course.title: Chasing Authenticity: Luther, Kierkegaard, and Nietzsche

course.description: This course examines the long standing habit in Russia of depicting its Muslim neighbors, and citizens, as Orientalized Others and/or enemies. Students look at texts spanning more than a thousand years of Russian and Eurasian history, to examine the figure of the Muslim in the Russian literary imaginary. In so doing, students gain a sense for the ever-changing relations between Christian and Muslim communities in Eurasia through the lens of their interactions in literature. Offered periodically.
course.name: The Muslim in Russian Literature

course.description: Healthcare spending accounts for a significant portion of gross domestic product and of the federal budget. It is one of the most consequential, and also one of the most complex, industries in this country and across the world. This course will examine the structure of American healthcare, the values explicitly and implicitly embedded in it, and opportunities to improve the system. Offered annually in spring. Prerequisite: BUS 110 Fundamentals of Business or by permission of the instructor.
course.name: Business of Healthcare
course.notes: Not open to first-year students.
course.prerequisites: BUS 110 Fundamentals of Business or by permission of the instructor.

course.description: This course equips students to act ethically in for-profit and non-profit business settings by introducing diverse ethical frameworks and encouraging the use of personal character strengths. Learners engage with moral dilemmas using these frameworks, complete a virtue profile analyzing their top five strengths, and participate in reflection posts and case studies to critically assess their ethical perspectives. Offered annually in the spring. Prerequisite: BUS 110 Fundamentals of Business or by permission of the instructor.
course.name: Business Ethics
course.notes: Not open to first-year students.
course.prerequisites: BUS 110 Fundamentals of Business or by permission of the instructor.

course.description: This course introduces students to the comparative study of Afro-Caribbean literature. Students explore the literature of the region after the 1950s in a relational framework to understand the commonalities and differences of its peoples, cultures, and literatures. Students read novels, essays, theory, and poetry from different linguistic and cultural areas of the region. Specific attention will be given to the genre of marvelous realism. Offered periodically in spring semester. Prerequisite: WRIT 120 or equivalent.
course.name: Afro-Caribbean Literature

course.description: This course focuses on tarot, a collection of cards used for multiple, unique purposes. The course discusses the origins and history of tarot, as well as examines the controversies surrounding the Rider Waite Smith deck. Using literary and cultural analysis, students will examine current iterations of tarot in literature and pop culture. Students will learn how to conduct tarot readings for themselves and others. Offered periodically. Prerequisite: WRIT 120 or equivalent.
course.name: Tarot: Past, Present, Future

course.description: This course examines the relationship between literature as a form of cultural expression and capitalism as a mode of economic production. Understanding literature's response to capitalism requires interdisciplinary study. This course thus seeks to contextualize the transformations of literature and capitalism by reading in the fields of political economy, sociology, political theory, critical race studies, advertising and marketing, visual art, and film. Offered periodically. Prerequisite: WRIT 120 or equivalent.
course.name: Literature and Capitalism

course.description: This course surveys traditions of writing about disability and the body in genres like fiction, memoir, journalism, manifesto, and diagnostic manual. Focus is given to neurodevelopmental conditions, physical impairments, and age-related debility. Through critical discussion of texts, students examine how somatic, bodily experience arises through encounters with human infrastructure and nonhuman ecology. Students also experiment with accessibility, usability, and emancipatory design to translate their own bodily perceptions into public essays, visualizations, and other digital media. Offered periodically. Prerequisite: WRIT 120 or equivalent.
course.name: Disability, Rhetoric, & Environment
course.title: Disability, Rhetoric, and Environment

course.description: This course introduces students to literary journalism, a tradition of in-depth nonfiction writing that reveals society's untold stories. Together, students discuss genre-defining texts from Joan Didion to The New Yorker. Students follow a slow journalism model used by magazine editorial departments, practicing investigative newsgathering using databases, public records, visual media, and interviews. Through deep work with sentence-craft, they develop a publishable longform article (or several shorter, linked works) in an area of their particular interest. Offered periodically. Prerequisite: WRIT 120 or equivalent.
course.name: Literary & Investigative Journalism
course.title: Literary and Investigative Journalism

course.description: In this course, students build an audition book of repertoire, surveying eras and genre-specific styles within the musical theater canon. Students develop an understanding of contemporary vocal styles unique to each repertoire category and practice techniques for both in-person and self-taped auditions according to industry standards. Coursework includes in-class and self-taped performances, goal-setting, and career preparation. Offered annually in Spring semester. Prerequisite: MUSPF 152 or MUSIC 148.
course.name: Musical Theater Lit

course.description: Students explore the intersections of music and community engagement through case studies on topics such as music and healthcare, education, Indigenous cultural agency, development, and immigration. Coursework includes a significant project developing a partnership between students and local community organizations. Students build skills in reading, writing, oral communication, project management, and community relations. Assignments include reading, listening, written reflections, research on issues relevant to community partners, and on- and off-campus engagement with community partners. Offered alternate years in spring semester. Prerequisite: MUSIC 141 Introduction to Musicology and MUSIC 237 Local and Global Musicking.
course.name: Music and Community Engagement
course.prerequisites: MUSIC 141 Introduction to Musicology and MUSIC 237 Local and Global Musicking.

course.description: This course serves as the 300-level requirement for the Nordic Studies Major. Its intent is to prepare students for advanced academic and professional work in the field of Nordic Studies. It engages critically with the question of what makes the Nordic countries distinctive, moving beyond common stereotypes to explore the complex historical, social, and political dynamics that have shaped the region. Offered alternate years in the spring semester. Prerequisite: Declared Nordic Studies Major and Junior or Senior.
course.name: Pro-Seminar in Nordic Studies
course.prerequisites: Declared Nordic Studies Major and Junior or Senior.

course.description: This course begins with a brief historical examination of the period from Abraham, whose "many sons" include both the Jews and the Arabs, through the Ottoman collapse and Mandatory Period to World War II. The chronology then slows and focuses primarily on the developments in the Middle East that have led to the current Palestinian Israeli crisis. Underlying this chronological structure, specific themes will be emphasized in each class, along with overarching themes like the roles of imperialism, nationalism, religion, and victimhood narratives. Offered periodically in spring semester.
course.name: Palestine Israel Crisis
course.title: History of the Palestine Israel Crisis

course.name: LAC - Russian
course.notes: Meeting time will be decided based on availability of the registered students.
Prerequisite: Completion of RUSSN 231 or equivalent experience. This course
cannot be wish listed. Add it after registering for RUSSN 268 (main course).
course.prerequisites: Completion of RUSSN 231 or equivalent experience. This course

course.description: This foundation-level studio course introduces the aesthetic, conceptual, and technical foundations of two-dimensional art-making and the ways drawing informs the creation and understanding of art in cultural contexts. Students explore color, value, form, and space through a wide variety of materials. The course emphasizes strategies for idea generation and visual problem solving. Students engage in spirited investigation, critiques, and thoughtful creative expression. Materials fee. Offered each semester.
course.name: Foundation 2-D Media
course.notes: The materials fee for ART 102 B will be $140.
This course has class-year limits.
course.title: Foundation Two-Dimensional Media

course.description: This foundation-level studio course introduces the aesthetic, conceptual, and technical foundations of two-dimensional art-making and the ways drawing informs the creation and understanding of art in cultural contexts. Students explore color, value, form, and space through a wide variety of materials. The course emphasizes strategies for idea generation and visual problem solving. Students engage in spirited investigation, critiques, and thoughtful creative expression. Materials fee. Offered each semester.
course.name: Foundation 2-D Media
course.notes: The materials fee for ART 102 C will be $140.
This course has class-year limits.
